> To support these goals, we needed the following concepts:
> 
> - =
Runner.  An extension to JUnit will likely define a custom 
> subclass of R=
unner.
> - Plan.  Each Runner must report a Plan, a hierarchical tree 
> of=
 the names of the tests it will run.  Test events are 
> reported with resp=
ect to leaves in this tree.
> - Request.  A Request is a specification of t=
he desired tests 
> to be run.  Extensions may also define custom subclasse=
s of 
> Request, in order to, for example, read tests to be run out 
> of a=
n XML file--if you think that's a good idea. :-)

This sounds very useful. =
It's a real pain that I don't have much
time to look at properly it at the =
moment, though I'll do what I can.

In particular, when writing my own para=
meterisation which allowed
parameterisation on a per test-method basis, I k=
ept running into this
kind of issue, in terms of how I'd "explain" to a uni=
t test UI what was
going to be run etc.

Unfortunately I can't (currently) =
release the source of my
investigations, but I'll try to apply the code I'd=
 written to the new
Runner/Plan/Request architecture and let you know how I=
 get on.

Jon
